titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Thomas Merton Center Records, 1962-2009 AIS.1982.19
titlestmt.author: Archives Service Center staff, Ian Hartman, Charles Stanford and Samantha Keenan. Revisions occurred to the finding aid as a part of the encoding process in January 2006.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-06-11 09:21:20 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: The Thomas Merton Center (TMC) of Pittsburgh is an affiliate of the International Thomas Merton Society. Growing out of Catholics in opposition to the Vietnam War, the TMC has since broadened its vision to encompass issues including nuclear weapons, South African apartheid, Central American counterinsurgencies, and crises in the Middle East. The material in this collection includes publications, subject files, pamphlets, correspondence, newsletters, and articles that reflect this wide array of activities.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: In 1972, in part to protest the Catholic Church's silence during the Vietnam War, the Thomas Merton Center (TMC) of Pittsburgh was established, affiliating itself with the International Thomas Merton Society. In these early years, the TMC, named after a trappist monk and peace advocate, not only voiced opposition to the Vietnam War, but was also active locally in many other issues. Primary among these was the desire to fight racism and end poverty. To this end, the TMC helped establish the Jubilee Soup Kitchen, the Greater Pittsburgh Community Food Bank, and the Pittsburgh Chapter of Amnesty International.

During the following decade, the TMC increasingly worked toward raising awareness of the Nuclear Arms build-up and wars in Central America. Throughout the 1980s, the TMC protested corporations such as Rockwell, Westinghouse, and IBM (among others) for their relationship with the Department of Defense. The culmination of these efforts resulted in the River City Campaign, launched with the goal of abolishing nuclear weapons. This campaign took aim at increased defense spending as the TMC along with community activists held protests, teach-ins, and conducted acts of civil disobedience. In the midst of these activities, the TMC was also vocal in their opposition to American involvement in Central American political affairs and domestic insurgencies. In their Sister City Campaign, the TMC organized a Witness for Peace Program that linked Pittsburgh and San Isidro, Nicaragua.

In the 1990s, the TMC was active in protesting the first Gulf War and later the "Contract With America" legislation of 1994 and 1995. Also during this time, the Tri-State Conference on Steel and the Citizens Budget Campaigns worked in conjunction with the TMC to fight the loss of well-paid industrial jobs in the Pittsburgh region. In the 2000s, the TMC worked to abolish nuclear weapons, protested the War in Afghanistan and the Iraq War and advocated for economic justice in the region.

The Merton Center continues to publish its monthly newspaper The New People, a publication dedicated to addressing issues of war, poverty, racism and oppression around the world. The TMC remains active in pursuing issues that they deem central to peace and social justice, acting as a resource for other like-minded organizations throughout the region.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of over 88 linear feet of material spanning from before the inception of the Thomas Merton Center in 1972 up to 2009. Materials in this collection are both regional and international in scope. Publications, subject files, pamphlets, correspondence, newsletters, and articles document the center's involvement and interest in political, social, and economic issues, such as women's rights, global poverty and inequality, and peaceful conflict resolution. Numerous other associations are represented in the records, including religious groups and non-governmental organizations (NGOs). The microfilm contains TMC and additional publications such as The New People, Update, Cease, and The Voice.

The records have been organized into series, reflecting periodic additions to the collection. More detailed scope and content notes are found at each series level. Series I, III, IV and V have large components of subject files, organized more or less alphabetically. Many subjects and activities are represented across multiple files and series. Researchers should search the collection widely for topics of interest.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Additional material received in 1994, 2001, 2005 and 2009. Further accruals are expected.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Thomas Merton Center through Molly Rush in 1982.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: A portion of the Thomas Merton Center records have been microfilmed; an inventory of this material is located in the Scope and Content Notes for the First Deposit.

odd.head: Previous Citation
odd.p: Thomas Merton Center Records, 1962-2009, AIS.1982.19, Archives Service Center, University of Pittsburgh

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Thomas Merton Center Records, 1962-2009, AIS.1982.19, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Ian Hartman in 2004, Charles Stanford, Carolyn Smith and Jessica Mirasol in January 2006, and Samantha Keenan in 2011. Revision and rearrangement for the encoded version of the finding aid provided by Cristela Garcia-Spitz in October 2005 and by Charles Stanford in January 2006. Information about the collection title and the controlled access terms was extracted from the MARC record in the University of Pittsburgh catalog Voyager ID number: 4613067.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into the following five series:

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series holds administrative files from the organization of the center and subject files from the first ten years of its existence. The subject files are arranged mostly alphabetical by box and cover a wide range of topics. Much of the information here deals with Vietnam/Indochina, Jimmy Carter, world hunger, and opposition to the B-1 bomber. Extensive material pertaining to the International Year of the Woman (IYW) in 1977 is also found here.

The two microfilm reels were also filmed in 1982. They contain chronologically arranged bulletins, election ballots, leaflets, announcements, and invitations to various activities, as well as several publications, including:
The New People (monthly), v. 1, no. 1 - v. 11, no. 6 (February 1972 - June 1982)
Update (an occasional mid-month bulletin), March 1973 - January 1975
CEASE (Catholics for an End to Asian Slaughter and Exploitation - irregularly published), April 1972, December 1972, December 1973
Seven Days of Light (by the Sisters' Council, Diocese of Pittsburgh and the Thomas Merton Center - annual), December 1972, December 1973
The Voice (Committee on Women, Diocese of Pittsburgh), v. 2, no. 1-4 (October, December 1977, February, October 1978); v. 3, no. 1-3 (March, October, November 1979); v. 4, no. 1-2 (April, June 1980)
Ballot, Annual Election of Board of Directors, April 1975 - April 1982

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains many periodicals, articles, publications, and correspondence from the 1980s that reveal the Merton Center's opposition toward President Reagan's domestic and foreign policy. Other items from this era include the River City Campaign (RCC), the Merton Center's nuclear freeze effort. The RCC organized gatherings, protests, and wrote articles and leaflets denouncing the military build-up, demanding that the money spent in defense be redirected to fight poverty. The RCC also worked to expose the large sums of money that corporations made through defense contracts. Indictments against Rockwell, Westinghouse, Nestle, and IBM are included.

The series also documents the Merton Center's activities in opposing military intervention and aid to what they viewed as corrupt regimes in Central America. Their effort to propagate a message of peace and unity resulted in the Merton Center's establishment of a Witness for Peace program, developing an ongoing dialogue between the Nicaraguan city of San Isidro and Pittsburgh. The series houses this correspondence. Events in the 1980s were held in solidarity with the persecuted in South Africa, and the series holds records of these, as well as meeting minutes of organizations formed to protest regional job loss. At the end of the series, Boxes 25 and 26 hold periodicals from the original 1982 accession. Some of them express the progressive wing of the Catholic Church which advocates Gay rights, the Equal Rights Amendment, and Central American land reform.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: These records, mainly from the 1990s, document the center's opposition to Newt Gingrich's "Contract with America" legislation and welfare reform, reflecting the specifics of their impact in the Pittsburgh region. There are also alphabetical subject files covering a number of social and political issues, with a significant amount of material pertaining to peace advocacy and military issues such as nuclear waste. This series also contains the records of the Mobilization for Survival and Jobs with Peace initiatives of the 1980s, including correspondence and meeting minutes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series continues the typical organization of subject and operational files covering a variety of social justice issues, as well as records relating to Thomas Merton Center training, events, awards, internships and reports. The bulk of the material in this series pertains to the following: Issues/Groups, Economy/Citizens Budget Campaign of Western Pennsylvania (CBC), the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities (CBPP) and Cooperating/Affiliated groups.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains a variety of Thomas Merton Center records from the years 1962-2009 and is organized into three subseries: Administrative Files, Subject Files and Audio/Visual. Administrative Files include records pertaining to the running of the Center. Subject Files include records pertaining to peace and social justice issues as well as a significant run of the Center's peace and justice newspaper, The New People, covering the years 1974-2008, though certain issues are missing, particularly from the 2000s. Audio/Visual includes photographs, slideshows, cassette tapes, sound reels, and VHS tapes, covering Center events and peace and social justice issues. Records are organized alphabetically within each subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Documenting the organization and administration of the Thomas Merton Center, these records include: volunteer records; financial/budget documents; board/staff documents; Center projects; staff and member retreats; and celebrations such as the Center's yearly award dinner recognizing an individual for their work in peace and social justice. A significant part of the subseries includes Giving Tree records, the alternative holiday gift shop run by the Center to support workers in third-world countries. The administration subseries includes materials from 1980 to 2009.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: These records in the subject files subseries span the Center's existence from 1962 to 2008. These files document the different regional and international peace and social justice issues the Thomas Merton Center brought awareness to, or organized against through projects and protests in an effort to bring about social change. Several folders are devoted to Pittsburgh-area projects that dealt with issues of racism, war, apartheid, hunger, the rights of women and children, and labor. Also included is a run of the Center's newspaper, The New People, which highlighted Center events, featured social justice articles, and acted as a source of information for other activists and like minded organizations on actions, campaigns, and events.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes a collection of over 500 photographs documenting Center activities, from staff retreats to community protests. Twelve slideshows used by the Center deal with issues including war, labor and world hunger. Over 120 cassette tapes, sound reels and VHS tapes feature speakers of varying prominence, speaking on the issues of peace and social justice dealt with throughout the rest of the collection.
